title: PCT 26: How the Blackfoot shared their wives
author: Mrs. Maggie Achenam

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êsa mînah êh-âyimisit ayahciyiniw wîwah kâ-kwâsihtwât.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê êsa mîna ê-âyimisit ayahciyiniw wîwa kâ-kwâsihtwât
sentences.english: Sometimes a Blackfoot brave's wife would be abducted.
“How is this?

sentences.original: namoya nkiskêyihtên awiyak âyiwâk ta-nâpêhkâsot iyikoh niya, itwêw aw îyahciyiniw.
sentences.english: I did not know that anyone was a greater warrior than I,” said that Blackfoot.
Then he searched; he went about throwing open the tipis.

sentences.original: nama nântaw miskawêw owîkimâkanah, êkwah kâ-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: nama nânitaw miskawêw owîkimâkana êkwa kâ-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: Finding his wife nowhere, he went away.
He mounted a fast horse, and looked for his wife.
He came to another village.
He searched in the tipis.

sentences.original: mêkwâc êh-nîswapicik ôhih kâ-kwâsihikot, kâ-paspapiyit onâpêmah.
sentences.text: mêkwâc ê-nîswapicik ôhi kâ-kwâsihikot kâ-paspâpiyit onâpêma
sentences.english: As the woman who had been abducted sat with her lover, there was her husband looking into the tent.
They fled through an opening in the tent.
The youth outran that Blackfoot and got away.
He went back; he went and reached his wife.
He questioned her: “Whose idea was it to elope and come here?”
“Mine,” said the woman.
“Now we shall go home,” said he.
Then he went home.
They arrived and went into their tipi.
Meanwhile the youth arrived.
Now he was worried: “Without delay he will kill me!”
Then that Blackfoot summoned him;
he summoned the youth who had abducted his wife.

sentences.original: kakwêcimêw êh-pîhtokêyit : tâns ôma, nisîm, k-ô-kî-sipwêhtêyan ?
sentences.english: When he entered the tipi, he questioned him: “How comes this, my younger brother, that you went away from here?
Whose idea was it that you two went away?”
“Your wife's; not mine.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê êh-tipiskâk, âsay êh-kawisimoyân, kâ-pê-koskonit, êh-isit.
sentences.english: In the night, after I had gone to bed, she came and woke me, saying to me, 'He will kill us; let us go away.'
She frightened me with her words.

sentences.original: niwaniskân; niwawêyîn; nipâskisikan, nimôhkomân, pakamâkan nôtinên.
sentences.english: I got up; I dressed; I took my gun, my knife, my hatchet.
'There, come!' I said to her.
And so we went.”
“Truly I am sorry, Brother, at what you two have done.
So now I shall have you as my younger brother.
Go drive my horses hither,” he bade his followers.
Quickly they drove them there.
He picked out two of his swiftest horses; he brought them to his tent.

sentences.original: êkwah otayôwinisah êh-mîkisiwiyikih, êkwah opâskisikan, ohpîhtatwânah miyêw. kiki nîso omîhkawikiw-atimwah ôhih okosâkah;
sentences.text: êkwa otayiwinisa ê-mîkisiwiyiki êkwa opâskisikan opîhtatwâna miyêw kiki nîso omîhkawikiwi-atimwa ôhi okosâka
sentences.english: Likewise of his beaded clothes, and a gun of his, and an ammunition-bag he gave to him, together with two swift horses, to his fellow-husband;
thus, in spite of rivalry, he accepted him and made him his brother.
The youth went home.
“So he did not kill you, after all?” he was asked.
“No,” he said.

sentences.original: êkwah wiyah nêô miyêw ostêsah masinasôw-atimwah.
sentences.text: êkwa wiya nêwo miyêw ostêsa masinasowi-atimwa
sentences.english: Then he gave his elder brother four brindled horses.

sentences.original: êko mînah pêyak iyahciyiniw otôtamôwin, kîhyawêmah kîpah êsah ê-kîh-kwêskêyihtahk, anohc mistah ê-kîh-kisiwâsit.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna pêyak ayahciyiniw otôtamôwin kîhyawêma kîpa êsa ê-kî-kwêskêyihtahk anohc mistahi ê-kî-kisiwâsit
sentences.english: This was another of the Blackfoot's ways, that he changed his mind exceedingly fast, when but now he had been very angry.

sentences.original: êyako minah mitoni kayâs ê-kîh-ihkihk tôtamôwin, ahpôh awiyah kâ-kitâpamâyit wîwiwâwa iyahciyiniwak, âsay ê-kîh-astêyimâcik wîstawâw.
sentences.text: êwako mîna mitoni kayâs ê-kî-ihkihk tôtamôwin ahpô awiya kâ-kitâpamâyit wîwiwâwa ayahciyiniwak âsay ê-kî-âsitêyimâcik wîstawâw
sentences.english: This too was a very old custom of theirs, that if anyone so much as looked at the Blackfoots' wives, at once they suspected him.
This has stopped;
the poor slaves are glad that their noses are no longer being out off.
They surely must have looked funny.
I wish we could have seen them; we should have laughed a great deal.

sentences.original: êyako pêyak kêhcik kêkway êh-ihtakohk, isih-nôtiniskwêwin.
sentences.text: êwako pêyak kêhcik kêkway ê-ihtakohk isi-nôtiniskwêwêwin
sentences.english: But this is a thing which no longer exists, this kind of fighting one's wife.
This is one of their customs that people tell of.
